Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Suggestion: add package comments" (#6042) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

I have a suggestion to improve the nuget.org website. I think the "comments" feature will be a great resource for getting feedback on packages. The Facebook comments would suffice. the change seems simple and the return would be fantastic. another suggestion would be to mark "stars" for users to evaluate the package. 

thanks

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Package remained verified after the organization owning the namespace was removed as owner of the package" (#6039) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
See PR: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/5984

The package is still verified after the organization owning the namespace was removed as the owner of the package. 
Observation: Everything in database seems to be cleaned.
1. The package has only one owner that is not the org or the org admin.
2. The namespace "cmaad" is reserved by the cmanutestorg
3. The ReservedNamespaceRegistrations does not have a reference to the package that is verified. 

Few UI snapshots:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16580006/41133712-640ae41c-6a7d-11e8-8277-302c78f0d286.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16580006/41133731-8586e776-6a7d-11e8-8947-21c0414aa193.png)


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16580006/41133765-b43b39aa-6a7d-11e8-8727-def1ab7918da.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Minor fixes for verify page." (#6038) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This addresses most of https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/5850

* Adds AI logging for any failure fed back to gallery during validation flow.
* Scrolls error message container into view on Upload page when Submit is pressed (if there are any errors to show). scrollIntoView tested on IE, Edge, Firefox, Chrome.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Merge RetrievePackageDimensions perf optimization" (#5957) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "Signing:  enable independent verification of primary signature and countersignature" (#6993) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Path to non-existing NuGetPackagesFallback folder generated into .nuget.g.props" (#7012) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
MSBuild 15.7.179.6572

MSBuild of an SDK-style project with PackageReference fails because the generated .csproj.nuget.g.props file contains this line:

```
<NuGetPackageFolders Condition=" '$(NuGetPackageFolders)' == '' ">C:\Users\kirillo\.nuget\packages\;C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\NuGetPackagesFallback\</NuGetPackageFolders>
```

The NuGetPackagesFallback folder doesn't exist on my machine, causing NuGet to fail the build with the exception:

```
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.1.201\Sdks\Microsoft.NET.Sdk\build\Microsoft.PackageDependencyResolution.targets(172,5): error MSB4018: The "ResolvePackageDependencies" task failed unexpectedly.
NuGet.Packaging.Core.PackagingException: Unable to find fallback package folder 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft SDKs\NuGetPackagesFallback\'.
   at NuGet.Packaging.FallbackPackagePathResolver..ctor(String userPackageFolder, IEnumerable`1 fallbackPackageFolders)
   at Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks.NuGetPackageResolver.CreateResolver(LockFile lockFile, String projectPath)
   at Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks.ResolvePackageDependencies.get_PackageResolver()
   at Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks.ResolvePackageDependencies.ResolvePackagePath(LockFileLibrary package)
   at Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks.ResolvePackageDependencies.GetPackageAndFileDefinitions()
   at Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks.ResolvePackageDependencies.ExecuteCore()
   at Microsoft.NET.Build.Tasks.TaskBase.Execute()
   at Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.TaskExecutionHost.Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.ITaskExecutionHost.Execute()
   at Microsoft.Build.BackEnd.TaskBuilder.<ExecuteInstantiatedTask>d__26.MoveNext() [C:\monodevelop\main\external\RefactoringEssentials\RefactoringEssentials\RefactoringEssentials.csproj]
```

None of the nuget.config files on my machine contain anything related to the fallback folder.

I don't have any environment variables set that start with NuGet*.

My VS offline package cache is a similar folder, but without the fallback:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/679326/41178607-a6f49062-6b1c-11e8-8b03-052d58ae5c01.png)

Why does NuGet decide to generate that non-existing folder into my .g.props files? 

Where does that value come from?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGetizer: NuProj With Multiple TargetFrameworks from Project References Cause Package Restore Errors" (#7011) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

After adding NuProj projects to package some Xamarin related libraries I started seeing a lot of NU1201 errors. I believe this is a result of the NuProj participating in Package Restore dependency chains of projects with multiple target frameworks. The repository that reproduces the issue can be found here: 

https://github.com/TheXenocide/Xamarin-Forms-Labs

I have tried a variety of experiments and was unable to get rid of all errors, though the state of the head of the repository is actually buildable, but not obviously. 

Opening the solution in Visual Studio on Windows will show a list of NU1201 errors and building will fail to restore packages, but if you use MSBuild /t:Restore on the command line even though it reports 100 errors related to target framework compatibility issues, the packages do successfully restore and then the entire solution can be built in visual studio (all assemblies compile, all nupkgs are generated, and our Directory.Build.targets customization automatically copies the packages the C:\Packages (by default). The Visual Studio error pane shows 24 errors, but the Output window says Build Successful. Note that NuGet.exe restore does not work, only MSBuild /t:Restore successfully makes the solution buildable.

Opening the solution in Visual Studio for Mac has some different oddities, but it feels like they may be related to our use of the "MSBuild.Sdk.Extras" NuGet SDK to allow us to use the new project format with our platform-specific Xamarin libraries (it doesn't think there's a "Debug" build target), but interestingly I'm able to use the MSBuild command line to both restore and build, each without any errors. Just for reference, I did try going back to the previous project format for the Android and iOS projects without using MSBuild.Sdk.Extras and, while Visual Studio for Mac got along with the projects better, this did not solve my package restore issues.

At first glance the obvious solution seems like I should just change TargetFrameworkVersion in each of the NuProj files to match the libraries they consume. I tried many varieties of this (TargetFramework netstandard2.0 in many cases, I tried TargetFrameworks to multi-target the NuProj, etc.) none of which work or seem necessary since the NuProj isn't actually producing a platform-dependent output itself; it infers  across all projects it references. In the end, no variety of TargetFramework(s) for my NuProj's worked as well as leaving them at the default TargetFrameworkVersion and just dealing with the fake errors on windows.

## Software Versions

NuGet.Build.Packaging Version: 0.2.2

Windows:
**MSBuild Version:** 15.7.179.6572
**NuGet.exe Version:** 4.6.2.5055
**Visual Studio Version:** 15.7.2
**NuGetizer-3000 Version:** 0.2.6
**OS Version:** Windows 10 x64 v1703 (15063.1088)

Mac OS:
**MSBuild Version:** Microsoft (R) Build Engine version 15.6.0.0 (xplat-master/ca830585 Sun Mar 25 19:24:09 EDT 2018) for Mono
**Visual Studio Version:** Visual Studio for Mac (Community) 7.5.2 (build 40)
**OS Version:** macOS High Sierra 10.13.5

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGetizer NuProj inconsistent between Mac and Windows" (#7010) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Visual Studio for Mac appears to have built-in support for .nuproj projects, but the projects generated by each are inconsistent. Projects created using the Visual Studio extension can not be loaded by the Mac without modification. Projects created using Mac can be opened with Visual Studio, though they do target NuGet.Build.Packaging 0.2.0 out of box. There are other substantial differences between the two project templates and it would be really nice to know what the ideal template looks like which will work consistently across mac and windows.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Installing signed package in offline environment" (#7008) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm in an offline environment with an in-house package server (using ProGet). If I try to install a signed package it takes 4 minutes until installation succeeds. 

How can I install signed packages in an offline environment without access to nuget.org?

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): NuGet.exe

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): 4.6.2 (Latest recommended)

dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate): - 

VS version (if appropriate): - 

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. nuget install cake -version 0.27.2 -source https://mylocalpackageserver

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

```
NuGet Version: 4.6.2.5055
Feeds used:
  C:\Users\Administrator\.nuget\packages\
  https://mylocalpackageserver



Attempting to gather dependency information for package 'cake.0.27.2' with respect to project 'C:\temp', targeting 'Any,Version=v0.0'
  CACHE https://mylocalpackageserver/Packages(Id='cake',Version='0.27.2')
Total number of results gathered : 2
Gathering dependency information took 134.67 ms
Summary of time taken to gather dependencies per source :
https://mylocalpackageserver	-	42.87 ms
C:\Users\Administrator\.nuget\packages\	-	16.26 ms
Attempting to resolve dependencies for package 'cake.0.27.2' with DependencyBehavior 'Lowest'
Resolving dependency information took 0 ms
Resolving actions to install package 'cake.0.27.2'
Resolved actions to install package 'cake.0.27.2'
Retrieving package 'cake 0.27.2' from 'C:\Users\Administrator\.nuget\packages\'.
Adding package 'Cake.0.27.2' to folder 'C:\temp'
Added package 'Cake.0.27.2' to folder 'C:\temp'
Added package 'Cake.0.27.2' to folder 'C:\temp' from source 'C:\Users\Administrator\.nuget\packages\'
Successfully installed 'cake 0.27.2' to C:\temp
Executing nuget actions took 4.01 min
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org API rate limits for package updates" (#24) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
|Spec wiki|Discussion issue|
|----------|------------------|
|*None*|https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/4679|

We have been working on improving the package submission workflow to reduce the overall time it takes to publish the package (right from package push/upload) till it's available for consumption and search. 

As mentioned on our [blog post](https://blog.nuget.org/20180201/NuGet-package-publishing-workflow-behind-the-scenes.html), the package availability gets degraded multi fold whenever there is a large number package uploads/updates by a single owner that clogs the package submission pipeline. Until we are able to scale to handle the large submission rate, in the short-term, we plan to reduce the rate limits for package pushes or deletes (unlist) per user.

The current [documented rate limits](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/api/rate-limits#package-push-and-unlist) will be updated to the following new limits once implemented. This change will go live, **soon** (within a week or two):

## Package Push and Unlist

| API | Limit Type | Limit Value | API usecase | 
|:---|:---|:---|:--- |
**PUT** `/api/v2/package` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **250 / hour** | Upload a new NuGet package (version) via v2 push endpoint 
**DELETE** `/api/v2/package/{id}/{version}` | API Key | ~~100 / minute~~ **50 / hour** | Unlist a NuGet package (version) via v2 endpoint
